content: holy cow 41 subscribers in three days this has
energized me so much that I felt the need to accelerate the schedule of this
video to today and to give you a sneak peak of video seven
and video 8 so a huge thank you to all my subscribe
and I hope that more will join now on to the main event the world is not square
and your dungeon shouldn't be either so here's slanted and curved tiles
we'll start off with a seven inch by seven inch square of double corrugated
cardboard mark off the center of each side at three and a half inches and
connect the lines to form a cross now you have the dead center of the square
identified from that intersection measure out and Mark in each of the four
directions a distance of two and seven sixteenths of an inch
get out your compass post it in the center widen it to any of the four marks
and draw a perfect circle you should see the circle pass through each of those
four marks as a further validation that the circle is indeed perfect this is
very important now cut the circle out I recommend a fresh blade and your utility
knife very very lightly follow the circle freehand you don't need to cut at
all on the first pass just lightly score the paper on the second pass press only
slightly harder you will find that the scoring you did helps keep the blade on
the right track the third pass is deeper and on the fourth you should be able to
get all the way through with the circle freed cut along the two lines in order
to obtain four perfect quarter circles these are the foundations for curved
tiles recall that the radius was two and seven sixteenths of an inch
that's because a curved tile is treated as a corner as far as the Foundation's
dimensions are concerned refer to video 2 for further explanation on that here's
a strip of our usual 3/4 inch chipboard for walls
pull it through your fingers like pulleys so as to induce a natural curve
to the chipboard this will make attaching to the foundation far easier
apply hot glue to the foundation and attach the wall chop off any excess I
recommend you do not attempt to cut the wall to link and then glue it because
having excess length on both ends gives you more leverage to hold on to while
the glue is setting now for the phone brick
peel the paper off and induce a curve as you did for the chipboard
dry-fit it mark and cut to the proper length
apply the brick texturing as was shown in video 3 then glue it to the wall last
apply the corrugation cover strips on to the diagonal pieces
measure out foundations that are two and seven sixteenths of an inch square cut
them in half diagonally apply the chipboard wall and cut it to length for
the foam brick dry fit it and cut to length note that the length of the foam
needs to match the length of the chipboard wall so you are making your
mark by looking at the still papered side of the foam apply the brick texture
and glue it in place then using the body of the foundation as a jig to feel when
the blade is parallel to the piece slice away at the small bit of foam that is
overhanging in theory this is a 45 degree cut last apply the corrugation
cladding see video for for the paint scheme or
better yet apply your own now we can attach the spaces there's going to be
some odd shapes here hold the tile over where it will be planted and look
straight down at it you want to be directly overhead and try to look
through the tile at where the wall is below it and draw a line there cut and
dry fit if you didn't chop off enough make a fine adjustment when it drive
fits correctly glue it down I'm going to let this just run for a bit so you can
see how this isn't an exact science and sort of requires a knack but I'm sure
you'll get the hang of it quickly you
how about some gameplay demos I'm going to do something
I haven't done before and just vamp so here's our hero and there's a black
pudding in his way that's not good but presuming he gets through that move on
to the diagonal hallway here we have a filled tile at the middle that that's
what allows it to be that wide we'll put a glyph of warding or something like

more here I'll call you a term tile board yeah a little more
